title: CTRL0000071074 - Transcribed Interview of Heidi Stirrup, (April 25, 2022)

data.text: JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL,
The deposition in the above matter was held via Webex, commencing at 10:04
For the SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE
THE JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL:
OF COUNSEL TO THE VICE CHAIR
This is a deposition of Heidi Stirrup, conducted by the House Select Committee to
Investigate the January 6th Attack on the United States Capitol pursuant to House
At this time, I'd like the witness to please state her full name and spell her last
This will be a staff-led interview.
I am Heidi Stirrup, last name spelled S-t-i-r-r-u-p.
My name i s - and I'm a senior
investigative counsel for the select committee as well as of counsel to the vice chair,
And I'll let my colleagues introduce themselves.
And members of the select committee may be joining us and leaving
during the course of the discussion.
it appears that there are no members on.
If any of them so choose, they may of course ask
We will do our best to announce on the record when they join.
So, at this time, I'd like Ms. Stirrup's counsel to please state his name for the
and I'm a professional staff member with the committee.
an investigative counsel for the select committee.
Under the House deposition rules, neither committee members nor staff may
disclose the testimony you provide today unless the committee chairman approves the
You and your attorney will have an opportunity to review
Now I'd like to ask that the court reporter please administer the oath to the
Do you solemnly declare and affirm under the penalty of perjury
that the testimony you are about to give will be the truth, the whole truth, and nothing
I understand that the witness has an opening statement she'd like to
make, but I'd propose that, before that, I'll just go over some ground rules for this
deposition, and then I'll give the witness an opportunity to make her opening statement
As you know, there's an official reporter transcribing the record of this interview.
You and your attorney will have an opportunity to review the transcript and suggest any
but the court reporter's transcript is the official record of the proceedings.
This deposition is being videotaped and audio recorded,
Please wait until each question is completed before you begin your response, and
we'll try to wait until your response is complete before we ask our next question.
purpose of this, of course, is so the court reporter can get an accurate record.
impossible for them to take down what two people are saying at the same time.
And, similarly, it's important that you give a verbal response to all questions rather
than a gesture, nodding or shaking your head.
You are appearing today pursuant to a subpoena from the select committee dated
statements that you make can constitute perjury as well as violation of 18 U.S.C. 1001, so
it's important that you tell the truth at all times.
As you know, you're under oath, meaning that any knowing false
It's important that you understand our questions, so if a question isn't clear, either
you or your counsel should feel free to say so, or if you can't hear us or don't understand
the question, please let us know.
Similarly, if you don't know the answer to a question or can't recall, you can say
so, but keep in mind that you're under oath so you have to be truthful.
recall the answer to the question, you do need to tell us.
You may only refuse to answer a question to preserve a privilege recognized by
may either proceed with the deposition and have your objection noted on the record or
seek a ruling from the chair on the objection.
you'll be directed to answer the question.
If you refuse to answer a question based on a privilege, the staff
If the chair overrules such an objection,
Of course, if you need to consult with your counsel at any time during this
interview, please feel free to say so.
You can simply -- we can go off the record at that
point, and you can turn off your audio and video so we can't see or hear you so you can
Similarly, if you need just a rest break, please say so at any time.
So do you have any questions about those ground rules?
I would just add, Counsel -- this is Chris Kachouroff for
Ms. Stirrup -- you know, if I think something is violative of the First or Fourth Amendment,
that's a right assertion as opposed to a privilege assertion.
that you're going to do that, but I just caution you in advance that, you know, if
So I just -- I don't perceive
something clearly falls within what I understand First Amendment case law to be, I'm
And, with that, Ms. Stirrup, would you like to give an opening statement?
Good morning, Mr. Chairman and members of the select committee.
the limitations on my testimony imposed by 28 CFR, section 16.22.
I appear this morning under subpoena.
As indicated in the final paragraphs of this statement, I also have general
subject to such objections in a good-faith effort to comply, to the extent I am able under
these constraints, with the select committee's request.
I reserve all objections here but offer my testimony
My understanding of the scope of the subpoena and the specific topics on which
the committee seeks information from me, as transmitted to me from the Department of
Justice, comprise the following limited areas:
Number one, conversations with Department of Justice officials regarding the
Department's investigations of allegations of fraud related to the November 2020
Two, knowledge of purported efforts to replace Acting Attorney General Jeff
Rosen with Assistant Attorney General Jeffrey Clark.
And, three, the appointment of Kenneth Klukowski and the appointments or
attempted appointments of other individuals to the Department to the extent they relate
to the select committee's focus and scope.
From what I can gather from the limited correspondence I've had with the
Department, which is summarized below, the Department's consent to my testimony
pursuant to 28 CFR 16.22, is limited to providing testimony only on these three topics.
I also note for the record, the committee's document requests are impermissibly
vague, and I find I must register an objection to these requests.
In particular, requests 1 through 6 and 8 through 22 contain language that is
references to documents, quote, "related to, relating in any way, or about," end quote.
The definition of terms contained in paragraphs 1, 2, 8, and 16 are similarly
deficient and also subject to objection.
In keeping with this understanding of the scope of the committee's inquiry, I offer
my testimony under the following conditions:
Number one, the Department knows and understands the scope and relevance of
my testimony on these topics and has offered all requisite permissions under 28 CFR,
Two, the committee agrees that the limitations on the scope of my testimony as
described in the Department's April 21, 2022, letter (see exhibit 1) are correct and that
the scope of questioning and responses will be limited accordingly.
And, three, I will object to any question where I have doubts concerning either my
own obligations under 28 CFR, section 16.22 or to the substance of any question that
might compromise my rights under the Constitution and the laws of the United States.
Specifically, my objections are as follows:
Neither the committee nor the Department of Justice has given me sufficient
prohibition on the production or disclosure of documents from the Department of Justice
in a proceeding in which the United States is not a party.
Twenty-eight CFR, section 16.22 contains a general
Both the committee and the Department are bound by the process set out in 28
CFR, section 16.22, which defines the parameters of any testimony I am compelled by the
section 16.22(a) precludes me from producing any material contained in Department files
or from disclosing any information related to or based upon material contained in those
Because I'm a former employee of the Department, 28 CFR,
It also precludes my disclosure of any information or producing any material
acquired as part of the performance of my official duties or official status without prior
approval of the proper official from the Department.
does not produce a proforma or blanket consent but, rather, is subject to the
In my view, neither the committee nor the Department has adequately complied
Although I requested that the Department approve my appearance and provide
access to the official records I need to respond to the committee's subpoena, neither the
committee nor the Department have, in my opinion, complied with 28 CFR, section
letter from the Department of April 21, 2022, attached as exhibit 1.)
(See April 20, 2022, letter to the Department, attached as exhibit 2, and the
One, the purpose of my testimony before the committee.
An essential part of the information I need to comply with 28 CFR, 16.22(a) is the
requested access to the correspondence between the Department and your committee
regarding facts the committee seeks to explore with my testimony.
that I'm not entitled to such information.
In furtherance of discerning the purpose, I've specifically
The Department graciously but disingenuously offered as a, quote, "courtesy" that
it first learned, quote, "of the subpoena after it was issued."
is, among other possible descriptions, neither helpful nor responsive, nor does it reflect
unquestionably in regular communication regarding former Department officials from
whom the committee is seeking testimony.
The committee and the Department are
Because there's no way for me to determine whether I have reviewed all materials
relevant to the select committee's inquiry, I will assume that the materials I have
reviewed are the only relevant documents and will limit my testimony accordingly.
Under 28 CFR, 16.24(c) and (d), the committee must provide a summary of the
testimony sought from me and disclose its relevance to this proceeding.
for such a statement but have not received one.
All I know from the Department is that my testimony is to be restricted to three
One, conversations with Department of Justice officials regarding the
Department's investigations of allegations of fraud related to the November 2020
Two, knowledge of purported efforts to replace Acting Attorney General Jeff
Rosen with Assistant Attorney General Jeffrey Clark.
And, three, the appointment of Kenneth Klukowski and the appointments or
attempted appointments of other individuals to the Department to the extent they relate
to the House select committee's focus and scope.
These are direct representations from the Department, not the committee.
Because the committee has not disclosed to me the nature and relevance of information
other than these topics, I will assume that these are the only authorized topics and will
Inextricably bound up with the legal constraints on my testimony and on any
documents subject to a request for production, the Department must make available to
me any and all records of whatever form maintained by the Department that I created,
received, or viewed in my official capacity at the Department.
possession or control of any such documents.
Moreover and most important, I am not the arbiter of the universe of such
documents as defined, particularly those described as having been, quote, "received or
viewed," end quote, in my official capacity at the Department.
requested access to all documents that fit the foregoing descriptions and while the
Department has represented to me that I have access to all such documents, I have no
assurance that this indeed is the case.
Of particular concern is my request that the Department identify all documents
that fit the above description and that have already -- I'm sorry -- quote, that
have -- quote, "already made available to the select committee that may relate to or be
based on my materials," end quote.
Because I have not seen the materials that the Department has made available to
this committee, I cannot determine in advance how or if any of these documents will be
relevant to the questions the committee will pose.
I will therefore scrutinize each document presented to me with great care.
Unless I can recall having seen it during the course of my review of Department
documents, I cannot and will not address its contents.
The powers, jurisdiction, and process of the select committee.
I am making the following general objections to this hearing and to the process
the select committee has established for its operations.
reservation of my rights under the Constitution and laws of the United States, I object as
For the record and in full
The select committee as constituted is not authorized by the rules of the
By the express terms of House Resolution 503, the majority of the House has
already determined that all of those who have voiced objections to the conduct of the
November 2020 Presidential election are, quote, "insurrectionists and domestic
terrorists," end quote, who must be indicted and punished.
As a result, this committee and the Department of Justice are colluding in an
investigative process that is not limited to legitimate issues of congressional concern,
such as security, preparedness, and coordination of law enforcement efforts, but, rather,
are conducting a law enforcement investigation into the, quote, "facts, circumstances,
and causes relating to the January 6, 2021, domestic terrorist attack upon the United
States Capitol Complex, hereinafter referred to as the 'domestic terrorist attack on the
Capitol,' and relating to the interference with the peaceful transfer of power and the
influencing factors that fomented such an attack on American representative democracy
while engaged in a constitutional process."
Taking a page from the infamous Judge Roy Bean, it seems to me that the
committee's conclusions and subsequent acts reflect a conclusion of guilt before trial.
This mindset is also reflected in remarks any some committee members reflecting
a prejudgment of guilt by those asserting their constitutional rights under the Fifth
For the foregoing reasons, I object to my compelled participation in this
investigation, which violates my rights under the Bill of Attainder Clause and the First and
Fifth Amendments to the Constitution of the United States.
Your statement is now on the record.
I'd like to show you exhibit 1, which we'll pull up, and this is the subpoena dated
March 8, 2022, which obviously you have seen.
Exhibit 2 will be the March 25, 2022, letter sent to you by the Department of
Justice, which you referenced in your statements.
I will just say for the record, rather than responding to any of the descriptions that
you made of those two documents, that the documents are in the record and speak for
So, going to exhibit 1, which is the subpoena, you understand you're
appearing here today pursuant to that subpoena.
And you understand that the subpoena asks for not only your testimony,
which we're getting today, but also for the production of documents.
indicated you don't have any responsive documents.
Can you confirm for the committee that you have done a reasonable search for
any responsive documents and found no responsive documents in your possession,
Did you use any personal email accounts for official business while you worked at
Did you use a personal cell phone, as opposed to a
Department-of-Justice-issued cell phone, for any Department of Justice work while you
worked at the Department of Justice?
Did you use any other messaging applications, like Signal, Telegram,
WhatsApp, or any others, for any Department of Justice work?
Did you keep any handwritten or electronic notes while you worked at the
Could you please tell us how you got hired to work at the Department of Justice?
From the Office of Presidential Personnel.
And how did it come about?
Well, first, where were you working
immediately before the Department of Justice?
The Department of Health and Human Services.
And how did it come about that you moved from the Department of Health
and Human Services to the Department of Justice?
The Office of Presidential Personnel was preparing for the second term of
the Trump administration and was considering political appointments in all of the
departments as to, you know, where they should be or where they could be or making
any changes, again, in preparation for the second term.
And did anyone in the Office of Presidential Personnel give you an
explanation of why they thought you should be White House liaison at the Department of
Well, I was the deputy White House liaison at Health and Human Services,
and they believed that I would be a good fit at the Department of Justice in that capacity.
As part of that process of appointing you to be White House liaison at the
Department of Justice, did anyone at the White House discuss with you what role, if any,
you should have in the Department's litigation of election-related cases?
Similarly, did anyone at the White House discuss with you what role you
should have in the Department of Justice's investigation of election fraud allegations?
And when did you start at the Department of Justice?
And when was your last day?
So you stayed -- and by that, your last day at the Department of
So you stayed at the Department of Justice all the way
until the inauguration of President Biden?
While you were at the Department of Justice, did you have any conversations with
any Department of Justice attorneys regarding their investigations of election fraud?
With whom did you have those conversations?
The chief of staff, Will Levi.
What about the Acting Attorney General, Jeff Rosen, after Mr. Barr left?
And when you say "not on that topic," the topic being
election-related investigations by the Justice Department?
Did you have conversations about DOJ's election-related investigations with
anybody at DOJ other than Will Levi and Bill Barr?
Did you have any conversations with anybody at the White House
If I did, it would've been with Spencer Chretien, and just -- nothing
I mean, nothing substantive; just opinion, right?
say -- because I was curious what the Department would be doing with regard to looking
at the allegations of fraud that, at the time, in the immediate aftermath of the election,
that were swirling around in the public domain.
To the best of your recollection, what did you say to Mr. Chretien?
To the best of your recollection, what did you say to Mr.
I think it was just sort of an expression of
exasperation over what I saw on election night as the results were coming in and I went
to sleep and I woke up the next morning to find out that it wasn't how I anticipated the
And so that, to me, was very troubling.
I guess I was asking not so much about your views on the 2020
Presidential election as specifically any conversations you had with him about DOJ's role.
So the kinds of conversations I would have with Spencer, as he was the
Department of Justice liaison for political appointments and I was the White House liaison
for the Department of Justice, I would speak with Spencer Chretien about potential
appointments to the Department -- in other words, personnel matters, political
role in career civil service appointments, transfers, promotions, nothing of the sort.
The White House liaison and political appointees have no
So I would speak to Spencer Chretien about political appointments -- potential
recommendations for certain candidates, and I would follow up with an interview or
So that's helpful to understand your role and the employment process.
in any of those conversations with Mr. Chretien, did you discuss the Department of
Justice's activities related to investigation of election fraud?
Did you have conversations with anybody at the Trump campaign regarding the
Department of Justice's investigation of election fraud?
Did you have any conversations with President Trump himself
regarding the Department of Justice's investigation of election fraud?
So can you just walk us through the conversation with Will Levi that you
I've never had a conversation with President Trump in my life.
How did it come about, and what do you recall saying to him?
It came about at my initiative.
As the White House liaison, I felt free to talk
to fellow political appointees at the highest level -- in that case, it was Will Levi -- to
express my concern about what I believed went wrong or was not correct or was, you
know, potentially fraudulent activity concerning the election.
I went to him to find out what the Department or anyone that he knew at the
Department was doing to look into and investigate fraud.
was brought forward and found no evidence of fraud.
And he told me that they -- he
He just said they looked into every allegation that
And I was in disbelief, I mean, over the fact that there was no fraud.
suggested that -- did I want to discuss this with the Attorney General himself, and I said,
Attorney General, and Will to express my concerns.
And so he arranged for a meeting with the Attorney General -- me, the
And before we -- I don't know if you were about to turn to that meeting, but
before we do, I just had some questions about your meeting with Mr. Levi.
Do you remember roughly when that was?
So it would probably -- it was either the Friday after -- no.
the Monday after -- because one of the points that Will made was that he worked on a
was having to devote to these questions and concerns about the election.
agitated and exasperated and exhausted, and he was complaining that he hadn't spent
time with his wife or family.
And he was very upset over all the amount of time that he
And this was -- you could just tell that he was extremely
And so I was not privy to that, you know, creation or writing of the memo, so I
I was not working over the weekend.
And so, you know, I was surprised
to hear it, but I was, I guess, relieved to know that they were in fact looking into
understanding what, if anything, could be done to look into the allegations of fraud.
So this four-page memo apparently Will described to me as something that would
be sent to the field to explain the authority by which the U.S. attorneys and others -- if
they were presented with allegations of fraud, you know, what their ability was to
rules by which one would investigate allegations of fraud if allegations of fraud were
brought to them by anyone for investigation.
So, in other words, making sure that everyone understood what were the
I'd like to show you what we're going to mark as exhibit 4.
from the Attorney General, and the subject is "Post-Voting Election Irregularity Inquiries."
Do you know, is that the memo that you were referring to?
And I'll show you now exhibit 3 -- and I apologize for going out of order, but -- this
The first one chronologically, so lower on the page, is from you to
"Would you send me a copy if possible?"
So was that a request from you to Mr. Levi for the memo that we were just
Yes, because, as you see in the subject line, the subject is "Memo."
And so, yes, I wanted to read it for myself.
And so Monday, November 9th, was the same day that you had the meeting with
And that was -- my meeting with Mr. Levi was around
12:00 or 12:30, and the meeting with the Attorney General was around 4:00 or 4:30.
And what made you think that the Department of Justice had not done enough
to -- or was not at the time doing enough to investigate voter fraud allegations?
Well, because I had not seen anything, really, that could be attributed to the
Department of Justice as to, you know, looking into allegations of fraud.
any evidence that -- of course, I wasn't privy to what they were doing, so I'm asking
questions, wanting to know for my own sake what was being done, what were they
It's not my place to do that, but, as a voting citizen of the United States, I wanted
This is -- in my opinion, the Department of Justice was the number-one law
enforcement department of the government, and if anyone had a role into looking into
this, it would be the Department of Justice.
me, elections -- he told me that there was no Federal role in elections, that elections are
But, as the Attorney General explained to
Did anyone ask you to look into the Department of Justice's investigations of
I'm sorry, what was the first part of the question?
Did anyone outside the Justice Department ask you to look into the
Justice Department's handling of investigations of voter fraud?
I had, you know, conversations with friends not in the
Federal Government, just people that I've known, who knew that I worked at the
Department of Justice and were asking me, "Heidi, what is going on?
And my answer was, "I don't know.
And so I -- no one asked me to look into this.
I don't know what is being
I asked -- I took it upon myself,
again, as a political appointee, to talk to my political colleagues at the Department to tell
me what, if anything, was being done.
And, like I said, the basic answer from Will Levi was this four-page memo.
then, when I spoke to the Attorney General, he said, yeah, there is no -- there is no role
for the Federal Government in elections.
And, therefore -- and I suggested to the Attorney General that maybe we should
issue an FAQ, frequently asked questions, document for the public so that they could
understand what he was explaining to me in case they didn't know, because I -- anyway, I
about what they and I felt was done on election night, which was highly irregular
And, anyway, I felt it would help ease the angst that the public was feeling
And by November 9th, of course, there were numerous anecdotes and
attestations, people that were poll-watchers saying all kinds of concerning things, and I
just thought that the Department of Justice could be looking into those.
But, as I said, I was told no.
And so -- but that attorneys, U.S. attorneys, around
the country could, if people brought forward, you know, allegations of fraud, that they
could -- well, whatever that memo said, that they could investigate.
So the memo, as I understand it, having, you know, reviewed it, is really about the
process for DOJ looking into allegations of election fraud.
you any of the actual investigations themselves --
But did Mr. Levi discuss with
Based on the fact that Mr. Levi suggested that you might want to talk to the
Attorney General and that you took him up on that offer, as you just described, it sounds
like you were still dissatisfied with what Mr. Levi was telling you.
Well, I guess -- yes, I was -- well, I mean, I wanted to make sure that -- it
wasn't that I doubted Will Levi, but I wanted to have the opportunity to express my
concern myself to the Attorney General himself.
So, if--you know, he -- again, he was very -- "he," Will Levi, was very agitated at
the time that I talked to him.
was doing everything it could legally within its responsibility to look into allegations of
And I just wanted to be reassured that the Department
Will Levi assured me that they were doing that, but I guess I wanted to hear it
I wanted the Attorney General to know that I
And so that happened -- I mean, the opportunity to speak to
So Jonathan Karl, in his book "Betrayal," at page 186, wrote that, on your first full
day in the office at DOJ, you went in to meet with, quote, "a senior official on Barr's team.
what she said was an attempt to steal the election," close quote.
She began the meeting by yelling at him for not doing anything about
Do you understand that to be a reference to the same meeting we're talking
about, the one with Will Levi?
I mean, this is the first we've heard of that.
This is a book, "Betrayal" by Jonathan Karl.
I mean, we could pull it up on the screen, if that's helpful to you.
I mean, I'm going to need a little bit of time to look at it
and go over it with my client, because I -- this is what I'd call an instance of sandbagging.
You've got to give me a little bit of notice on this.
Am I able to drive this, or no?
Just tell us if you want us to move it around.
I can't just spring this stuff on her, you
We'll pull it up on the screen.
I'm going to take us off video and mike.
Can you go to the point -- because you're now scrolling back up.
And so I was reading down, and now you're going up.
Can you start this where you are
Let me read it with my
passage, so just give us a second.
We're just working on finding the appropriate
The paragraph starts at the bottom of 185,
and we can scroll down a little bit if you'd like.
And so what I was reading from is at the end of that
paragraph that carries over from 185 to 186, starting with "On her first full day in the
You can go down a little bit, please, so I can start with the "'White House liaison'
Just give me just a moment to look at that, okay?
sounds like a lofty" -- all right.
Can you go down a little bit more, please?
You can go down a little bit, please.
If we can scroll back up to the top of page 186, the quote from Mr. Karl is:
"On her first full day in the office, she went in to meet a senior official on Barr's team.
what she said was an attempt to steal the election."
She began the meeting by yelling at him for not doing anything about
Does that -- I'll give you an opportunity in just a moment to say
whether you agree with that description, but does that sound like the meeting that we
have been talking about, the one you had with Mr. Levi?
And I do take exception to this entire characterization.
Yes, because I only had the one conversation with Mr. Levi on that one day.
Jonathan Karl -- never spoke to me and is attributing things to me that simply did not
happen the way he is describing them.
First of -- well -- so I object to this characterization.
What parts in particular -- let's just -- we can go through it in pieces.
But that passage that I just read, what parts, if any, of that do you dispute?
You can ask questions about her personal knowledge, what she
You know, this is something we've never seen before.
Did she meet with Bill Barr?
Is she going to tell you that she yelled at him?
You don't yell at -- a White House -- she'll tell you, a White House liaison
I'm not testifying, but I'm objecting to you asking her about a
That could go on for hours.
She just said it's not true, and you're asking her for why it's not true.
I mean, how about giving me a little specific question, "Did you yell at Barr?", and
don't -- the questions you're asking her are vague.
"When you were there for your first full day in office, did you go
You can ask sentence by sentence if you want to.
It was two sentences, but if you want to go sentence by
sentence, we can go sentence by sentence.
"On her first full day in the office, she went in to meet a senior
Ms. Stirrup, did you, in fact, on your first full day in office go in to meet with a
My first full day was October 25.
I believe that was a Saturday.
The next day, I started at DOJ.
But it was one of those two days.
My first full day in the office was that
It could've been October 26th or 25th; I don't have a calendar in front of me.
And so my first full day in the office was October 25th, and I did not go in to meet
a senior official on Barr's team.
That would've been 2 weeks after I have been in the office.
And that occurred -- you met with Mr. Levi on Monday,
"She began the meeting by yelling at him for not doing
anything about what she said was an attempt to steal the election."
1began the meeting by asking him a question about what was being done
with regard to the election irregularities.
The next sentence has -- next two sentences, I guess, has a quote:
Did you yell at Mr. Levi?
wake up to the fact that this election is being stolen!', she screamed.
I was questioning what took place on election day and the counting and the
Do you recall saying something to that effect?
results that were apparent the evening of the election and what was announced the
If we scroll down a couple paragraphs, the paragraph starting with "The next time
"The next time Stirrup came around to berate the senior
official, he asked her if she would like to deliver her message directly to the Attorney
General, and with that he brought her in to see Barr."
Is there anything about that sentence that you think is inaccurate?
The only time I spoke to Will Levi was Monday,
I told you that Will Levi's frame of mind on that Monday was extremely agitated.
thing he wanted to see was me asking more questions.
many, many others similar kinds of questions.
I'm sure he had been asked by
I can't believe I'm the only one who was
So I did not -- "the next time" is inaccurate.
He did ask me if I would like to, not deliver my message directly, but to meet with
the Attorney General and ask him these questions, is basically what he said.
agreed, yes, I would like to do that.
General later that afternoon, about 4:00 or 4:30.
And he did arrange for me to see the Attorney
So that's the afternoon of Monday, November 9th?
Essentially, Mr. Attorney General, I am concerned about what I feel has
And it was just you, Attorney General Barr, and Mr. Levi.
And what did you say to the Attorney General?
been, you know, voting irregularities, fraudulent activities.
These are the kinds of things
that were in the public domain, being discussed, about people that were directly involved
in various States and various voting locations, their personal attestations of what they
saw which they believed was highly irregular, if not illegal.
And he basically said -- and I asked him if he would be -- you know, what was
being done, basically, to look into this.
And then he said there is no Federal role in
elections, that elections are run at the State level, and that if there were allegations
brought forward in individual States to the Department of Justice U.S. attorneys in those
States, that they would have the authority to investigate.
